title: Rear Brake Master Cylinder - Removal

body.body: Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
If the engine has recently been running, the exhaust components can be hot.
Always allow the hot components to cool before working on the exhaust system.
Contact with the hot components could cause minor to moderate burns to exposed skin.
Notice - Do not spill brake fluid
To prevent paint damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork.
Spilled brake fluid will damage paintwork.
The brake caliper will require removing and the pistons pushed out to back bleed the master cylinder as part of the brake bleeding procedure, see
Remove the rear wheel hanger from the rear brake caliper assembly and support the brake caliper.
Make sure no damage is made to the brake pad material when moving the brake pads.
Allowing the brake pads to come into contact with each other or sharp objects may cause the material to crack or break.
Damage to the brake pads may result in reduced braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.

Using a suitable flat metal plate approximately 2 mm thick and 30 to 50 mm wide (for example a gasket scraper) between the brake pads, pump the rear brake pedal until the plate is held by the brake pads.
Release the fixing and detach the rear brake fluid reservoir from its bracket.
When disconnecting the brake hose from the master cylinder it is necessary to keep the open end of the hose in an upright position.
Allowing the brake hose to fall downwards will allow an excessive amount of air to enter into the brake system.
Trapped air may cause the brake lever to feel spongy and contribute to reduced braking efficiency.
Release the fixings and remove the right hand heel guard.
Release the fixings and detach the right hand control plate and brake master cylinder assembly from the frame.
Release the fixings and detach the brake master cylinder from the right hand control plate.
Noting it's orientation for installation, disconnect the brake hose from the master cylinder, discard the washers and secure the end of the hose such that it remains in the upright position.
Allow the brake fluid to drain from the master cylinder outlet into a suitable container.
Remove the clip and clevis pin and remove the master cylinder. Discard the clip.

body.name: Rear brake mstr cyl removal B02410

Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
If the engine has recently been running, the exhaust components can be hot.
Always allow the hot components to cool before working on the exhaust system.
Contact with the hot components could cause minor to moderate burns to exposed skin.
To prevent paint damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork.
Spilled brake fluid will damage paintwork.
Perform the following operations:
Rear Wheel - Removal
The brake caliper will require removing and the pistons pushed out to back bleed the master cylinder as part of the brake bleeding procedure, see
Bleeding the Rear Brakes
Remove the rear wheel hanger from the rear brake caliper assembly and support the brake caliper.
Brake caliper assembly
Rear wheel hanger
Make sure no damage is made to the brake pad material when moving the brake pads.
Allowing the brake pads to come into contact with each other or sharp objects may cause the material to crack or break.
Damage to the brake pads may result in reduced braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.

Using a suitable flat metal plate approximately 2 mm thick and 30 to 50 mm wide (for example a gasket scraper) between the brake pads, pump the rear brake pedal until the plate is held by the brake pads.
Release the fixing and detach the rear brake fluid reservoir from its bracket.
Fixing
Bracket
Brake fluid reservoir
When disconnecting the brake hose from the master cylinder it is necessary to keep the open end of the hose in an upright position.
Allowing the brake hose to fall downwards will allow an excessive amount of air to enter into the brake system.
Trapped air may cause the brake lever to feel spongy and contribute to reduced braking efficiency.
Release the fixings and remove the right hand heel guard.
Loosen the hose union bolt.
Release the fixings and detach the right hand control plate and brake master cylinder assembly from the frame.
Heel guard
Heel guard fixings
Control plate fixings
Control plate
Release the fixings and detach the brake master cylinder from the right hand control plate.
Noting it's orientation for installation, disconnect the brake hose from the master cylinder, discard the washers and secure the end of the hose such that it remains in the upright position.
Allow the brake fluid to drain from the master cylinder outlet into a suitable container.
Remove the clip and clevis pin and remove the master cylinder. Discard the clip.

Union bolt
Sealing washers
